description.text: It is like a small piano but I use tubes with different thickness instead of strings. So when you push the bottoms, the little hammer will hit the tube and make sounds. As the thickness of the tube changes, the sound will change. Likewise, every part of each key is separated and completely the same. All the part are interchangeable  and can be group freely, which means, if you want, you can make a huge key boards. There is NO LIMITATION.

This is a plug for a outlet on a Intex pool. I created it because I had a dream of running my solar pool heater on it's own pump. After 2 years of being scared of carving a extra hole in my pool, I gave it a go, while it was already full!

5% and accelerated. The project was a success. I bought some heavy duty pool vinyl and added reinforcement to the area where I wanted the hole. I did get a little wet, but I bet I did not lose more than a few gallons of water in the process. Intex pumps come with the plastic pieces and washer that is needed for each hole. I have had to replace pumps in the past, so I had a extra set. I used the outside ring as a marker and a real sharp x-acto knife to cut the hole. I used a plastic shoe box on the inside of the pool to limit the water that came out. Once cut out, I put all the parts where they needed to be and tightened them. Voila!

author: Frugalshave

description.text:
A friend of mine asked if I could create a display for an Arrow won at one of our tournaments. The two targets are filled with 3-4 quarters on each side ($2 total) or like weight.  
I needs a better base. I will need to go on a hike to find an interesting piece of wood to use as the base.  
I have also found that it is a fun target for Nerf Darts!

Print the Arch and two of the covers. The Arch should fit 3-4 quarters on each side snuggly. Use the two lids to finish up the covers. Paint if you like.   
Currently the center hole fits a 800 series arrow, but it can be drilled or modified to fit larger diameter arrows.   
Find the desired balance point of the arrow. I found that a little tape at that point would keep the arrow in place.  
Embed a half arrow with tip at an angle into a piece of wood or base of your choice.   
Balance the trophy on the arrow tip and enjoy.

UPDATE - Added some pictures of the printed out model - these were done in transparent PLA with the intention of spray painting it orange to get some nice translucency Miniature Pumpkin Lantern for hanging. Designed to contain a 3v circular battery like a CR2032 combined with a 3v LED. Hobbyist build with no electronics knowledge required. Simply print out all pieces
Insert the battery into the base groove
Slide the LED legs over the battery (positive anode to positive terminal, negative to negative...LED will turn on if put on the right way.
Then simply put the top on...I suggest using blue tack to stick the pieces together so you can replace the battery if required...if not then glue the pieces together.
Insert hook into top hole with glue...may require minor sanding to fit hole. Hope you enjoy the model

This was designed all in 123d Design.
The STL file size was then reduced by exporting the file in Meshmixer
File was then checked in Simplify3D for mesh errors and general analysis

title: Kore - Easy. Extendable.
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: Kore is open-source hand tool, designed to provide individuals with poor motor control ways to interact with the world around them. With extend-ability in mind, Kore can easily be adapted to perform all kinds of functions!

• Strap anchors to ensure you don't lose grip of your Kore
  • Interchangeable tooltips
  • Customizable grip
  • Easy assembly
  • And it's Open Source!

Kore comes with six different pieces at first, held together by two common household screws. Simply slide the Kore base inside the grip, attach a Strap Disk to each end, place the Kore Cap on one end and fasten it with a screw, then do the same on the opposite side for the Tool Guard with another screw.
Voila! Your done! Now print off an included tooltip, or design your own, and get interacting!
Kore utilizes what we like to call "tooltips." Simply snap a Kore-compatible tooltip into the end of Kore and get interacting!

Right now, a few Kore tooltips have already been designed, but have yet to be uploaded, such as:
  • Forks
  • Knifes (ooh!)
  • Spoons
  • Styli
  • Key holder
    • Uploaded so far:
  • Pen / Pencil holder
  • DIY Base
    • Want to design your own? Check out the "Kore_Tooltip_Base" file and get started!

Kore is designed from the ground up to allow collaborative creation and innovation, and already there's a need for it. With your help, we can continue to design new and innovative tooltips to extend Kore's functionality beyond what's imaginable. Better with lists? Here a TODO:
  • Clean up bottom of Sketchup components, it seems some faces are missing.
  • Design new tooltips.
  • Work to reduce 3D print time, right now it's estimated at exactly 12 hours on a Makerbot Fifth Generation Replicator at Standard Print Quality.

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

Standard

Infill:

10% - 30%

Notes: Current estimated print time is exactly 12 hours with all parts at 10% infill / Standard Quality, except for the base, being printed at Low Quality. Print Strap Disk twice and attach to each end of your Kore, one nestled between the Kore base and Cap, and another between you Kore base and Tool Guard. Tested on a Makerbot Fifth Generation Replicator
Assembly To assemble Kore, all you need is any two household screws: Simply snap the parts together, insert a screw into each end of your Kore, and attach a tooltip to the Tool Guard on the end.

comments.text: Its now a bit clearer to me. If you are hoping for people to contribute designs for attachments I suggest you put a detailed description of all the design elements and their functions so people understand how their design will work with the kore and where their attachment will mount.

comments.text: Thanks! Kore actually doesn't include a variable center of gravity, but that's a wonderful idea! As for the attachments, I'm actually uploading a template right now and updating the contributing guidelines.

comments.text: I like your thinking behind the design but to make the design better I would suggest to have it so that you can attach a regular fork or pencil to it. This way it would be a little more practical in everyday use and save on plastic by not having to print out the extra parts for the tooltips. One way I think you might be able to do this  is have the inside hollow and have some sort of a clamp on the inside that could be tightened by a knob on the side. Other than for that this seems to be a well thought out design.

Mini FPV Tricopter This thing is a work in progress, so may be updated over time as I try out different motor/esc combinations.
Designed using autodesk fusion 360 To complete the tricopter, you will need either 2204 or 1806 motors X3
5 or 6in props
Savox SH-0257MG servo
6mm diameter carbon fibre tube for arms cut to 150mm length X3
Power distribution board
5v UBEC if using DYS ESCs
I use DYS20A BLHeli ESC's X3
Naze32 / Mini KK2 or mini APM compatible FC
I use a Naze32, however if you use any other FC other than the naze, don't print out the cover, as it only fits the Naze32 boards If using the 1806 motors, please print the spacers for the front arms Designed for the mobius action cam and 1000mAh 3s batteries. Added, landing gear adapter, fits universal landing legs

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.20mm layer height

Infill:

50%

Notes: I used supports on the the motor mounts. On the top plate, the counterbores (wide screw holes) need to be on the the bottom layer when printing otherwise you may not be able to bolt the top half to the bottom cleanly.

A crown gear and pinion are used to turn the dirction of rotation about 90 degrees. This one is small with the pinion only about 12mm and the crown about 36mm. It can be scaled up so long as you use the same scale for both part (Obviously- right?). But, I made them this small for use in small models. The pinion as it is made has a 3mm shaft hole with a boss for a set screw. about 4-40 in thread. Really, its just a demonstrator gear set., since the teeth are a bit fine for anything too powerful. But, it does work.

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Once again, Autocad first then imported into 3-D Design. I pretty much made this design up from scratch, nothing to say it is this or that specific established gear tooth standard. Just something that sort of meshed and made sense. Like I said earlier, it's a demonstrator set only.

-. Eagle (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:786002)
-. Monky King (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1066947)
-. Puppy (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1087797) I modified and redesigned these characters. I combined two ( a character and a whistle) into a character whistle by using Autodesk Meshmixer(http://www.123dapp.com/meshmixer). Each whistle has 2 different mouthpieces (with one hole and two holes, respectively). The mouthpiece with two holes creates a higher frequency (pitch) sound. Each character whistle can produce about 90 decibel sound. So, you can also use it as an emergency whistle for natural disaster situations, crime prevention and scare animals. Choose a character whistle you love, print it, and blow it!

author: T311

description.text:
In English below: Una piccola modifica per avere le regolazioni del piatto più comode. Basta fare quattro fori svasati nelle posizioni indicate nella foto dagli ellissi rossi. Si utilizzino 4 viti svasate M4x30mm al posto delle M4x20mm originali.
Si montino le prolunghe alla base in alluminio inferiore e le viti per la regolazione (con le rotelle) tra le prolunghe e la base di alluminio superiore (quella su cui abbiamo fatto i 4 fori). Si assembli come nelle foto!
Il sistema dovrebbe garantire la rigidezza necessaria! English: A little change to improve the comfort during bed regulation on a 3drag. Drill four countersunk holes (see the red circles in the pic for the positions). Replace the original M4x20 mm countersunk bolts with four M4x30 mm countersunk bolts.
Assembly four prolunghe4.stl on the lower alluminium plate. The upper alluminium plate (where we did the four countersunk holes) has to be fixed to the lower part using the four M4x30 mm bolts inserting two wheels (rotelle3_nut.stl) for each bolt for regulation.
In my opinion the system is stiff enough! Enjoy

This small brushless DC motor can be controlled with anything from a simple RC flip-flop to an Arduino and is part of the Learning in a Makerspace chapter of my new book new book "The Makerspace Workbench" from Maker Media! Cut out the parts on 1/8" plywood using a laser engraver and glue together. Each coil is made from a 1/4-20 x 1/2" bolt and wound using coated coil wire. The armature is made out of a short piece of 1/8" aluminum rod and two donut magnets.

Optimally there would be three or more poles.

title: Mic Scoop for Microsoft Live Cam

description.text:
When using the Microsoft Livecam's mic for conferencing I noticed the background noise was cutting my audio out.
so, I took a moment and put something together, and 17 minutes later I had a solution. Full disclosure : I haven't yet tested to see if the background noise is blocked, however, I am confident that the directional sound scoop will help a little for our busy little office. The Uploaded STL file allows for what I hope to be a mechanical ring fit. The one I printed with a partial ring clip is held to my camera with a dab of crazy glue to keep it from spinning. (see pictures)

description.text:
Normally my fingers get squished whenever I try to remove Teensy breakout boards, so I whipped this up to make removal easier.
Slip each end underneath a Teensy PCB (or your PCB of choice that fits) and rock back and forth with a pulling motion to remove.
For more control, the fingers can snap together to grip the PCB. The best way (i've found) of reliably getting this to happen is using a thumb on the word 'PCB' and whichever finger comes naturally on the other side.

title: Wanhao Duplicator i3 end braces and Z-braces

description.text:
EDIT - 09.11.2015
I added some simple rod ends with holes for M3 screws for adding braces to support the Z-assembly. They are angled so that the rods align with the bolts. I made my braces with 335mm long 5x6mm carbon fiber tubes with screws glued in the ends. 3mm carbon rods or 3mm inner diameter tubes with M3 threads glued in will be perfect. Use your maker ability to make the rods from materials available to you. RC shops usually carry carbon rods and tubes of various sizes. Use a 90° angle square to tram the Z-assembly in relation to the leveled bed. 335 mm long rods between the printed ends gave me a square printer.
I also reduced the height of the watermark so that it doesn't stand out as much.

These braces/stiffeners for the end plates on the Y-axis frame add a little rigidity to the flat sheet metal and also have four 26mm diameter feet for which to apply some rubber feet. Rubber pads often come in a 1" diameter, so they will fit nicely under the feet. The ends have holes for inserting M3 screws for attaching braces for the vertical Z assembly. I suggest using M3 ball ends. There is one version for the back and one version for the front. They will install without disturbing the alignment of the printer if you take care and make sure the remaining screws on the ends are tight. Requires:
12 ea. M3x12mm or longer screws.

Ever put your phone down for a second and spend the entire day searching for it? If yes, then these cuffs are for you! They will ensure that you and your phone will not be separated, and you’ll still be able to use your phone (although not much else). Attach the clip on one end of the chain to your iPhone 6, and have a friend help cuff you. While you’re wearing these cuffs, feel free to reflect on technology’s constant presence in the modern community. Although it’s easy to check your news and communicate on the phone, being immersed in the world of an iPhone screen’s pixels can pull you into a prison of indifference and dependence. This design may at first be a device to keep your phone from running away from you, but you can’t take the cuffs off by yourself. Ultimately, you will be the one in handcuffs, a prisoner to modern technology.

Designed for an '06 Honda Civic (should work with similar year imports). There is an outside which is what you would hold and an insert screws into the shift rod on the car. The threading inside the insert are 10 x 1.5. I printed the outside in Laywoo-D3 filament to get a classic wood look. This was my first big project using this filament and it worked out great! Hope you enjoy. The CustomShiftKnobCutout is for personalizing other things into shift knobs. An Instructable for more customization can be found here http://www.instructables.com/id/Customized-3D-Printed-Gear-Shift-Knobs/

Outdise- Printed using default accelerated print settings on a makerbot replicator. No raft  no support. Worked out pretty well, but because i used Laywoo-D3 it had a hard time filling holes at that speed.  I would suggest non accelerated setting for Laywoo-D3 otherwise it should work great for ABS or PLA.   
Inside- Printed using default accelerated print settings, 60 percent fill in.  No raft no support.  The more fill in the better because it has to bare the strain of screwing on the the shift rod.

title: Chimney View Finder for Lomo Konstruktor DIY SLR Camera

description.text:
A printable Chimney style View Finder, for the Lomography Konstruktor SLR camera. Using a cheap Loupe from Utrecht, and these 3D printed parts, you can make your own. The magnification is a little less intense than the standard view finder loupe, but you can now see the ENTIRE frame brightly, instead of just the very center. Also because the whole top is closed off less light leaks in making for a more contrasty view. Here is a link to the Loupe I broke apart to get at the magnifying glass:
http://www.utrechtart.com/Testrite-Seerite-1in-X-1in-Linen-Tester-MP22071-i1007896.utrecht

-Download the All_Files.Zip file -Print the parts (Without support, that's how I designed them to be printed) Note I have includes the GCODE, and .X3G file, so you can literally print it exactly like I have. My original Solidworks file is also included if you want to modify the file. Here is more technical detail on my settings:
Object infill: 25%
Layer Height: .1mm
Number of Shells: 1
Feed Rate: 40
Travel Feedrate: 55
Print Temp: 230
Slicing Profile: Replicator 2 Slicing Defaults. -Order the Loupe
http://www.utrechtart.com/Testrite-Seerite-1in-X-1in-Linen-Tester-MP22071-i1007896.utrecht -Break it apart -Spray it a dark color (So light doesn't leak through) -Glue the parts in place -Slide onto Konstruktor -Use!

This is a mount I designed for a iMac stand from an old 2004 iMac that converts the iMac mount to a standard vesa 100 mount. This piece allows you to take a vesa 100 (100mm x 100mm) monitor mount and attach the beautiful iMac stand to it adding a nice look to your monitor for only some screws and this 3D printed piece. Instructions: To attach the bracket you will need:
M4 .7 pitch 8mm long screws x4 for the monitor
and M4 6mm screws with nuts x4 for the iMac stand Now screw everything together and tighten the spring side of the iMac stand that lets you tilt the monitor to keep it from falling to the downward position from the weight of the different monitor, and remember that if your monitor is extremely thick compared to a regular monitor this will not work for you since it may be too front heavy.

author: UltiKid

description.text: A model of the basic racer kit sold to boy scouts for use in their Pinwood Derby races. The dimensions are as close as I could measure using the BSA-approved kit I purchased at the hobby shop for reference. The intent is for boy scouts to sculpt a virtual model of their design in 123D Design before making the real car for the race.

Really fortunate scouts may end up using their dad's desktop CNC router to mill out their model, though this hardly seems fair.   
Boy scouts who really want to push the limits of the rules may try cutting down their block to a mere base frame and then 3D print a case to fit over it, but do this AT YOUR OWN RISK. You may be disqualified. I don't know if anyone has ever tried this or if it was allowed.  
I think the Boy Scouts may need to reconsider their rules. Desktop manufacturing is going to factor in these competitions, if it isn't already.  
Whatever you do, be sure to double-check the final results against the rules and regulations for your troop's race and measure carefully. My model may be slightly off.

comments.text: Take it from a 6 time 1st place winner who used the same car every year. The wedge car wins every time. Keep balance center or slightly forward and use graphite powder on the wheel nails, you'll kill them every time. Untill someone else who knows the same secret comes up with the same car, then it's a matter of sanding and tuning to make it faster. Simpler always wins, air resistance is the thing that slows you down. They all weigh the same and use the same hardware, it's meant as an engineering lesson, simple is always better. There's an old saying. KISS - "keep it simple, stupid"
comments.author: DevWolf

comments.text: Wedge might win, but no points for style. :)

description.text: I made the SmartLCD Case http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:80065 but it was missing a button so that you could push the the software kill switch. So I made this add-on button extender. Now when things go crazy I have an instant way to stop everything.

Just print, insert into front of case while it faces down then add the SmartLCD board and back panel on top. Since all I had was white ABS plastic, I colored mine red with a permanent marker.  
When you push the button it shuts down everything instantly and goes into a do nothing loop. The LCD display freezes so you can analyze what was happening. You need to reset the processor to get things running again.

author: Tarco

description.text: A quick and easy Tinkercad design, just for fun!

This Chinese takeout box is an art project made to illustrate the westernization and devaluation of Chinese food in America. The fact that the box is crumpled represents how the quality Chinese food in a western point of view equates to that of fast food, as well as the lack of appreciation and respect for the food that serves as a culturally important icon. The eating utensil, formed by a fork and chopsticks, further demonstrates the dominance of westernization and cultural imperialism.
After printing the box, make sure to use a metal wire to create handles for it, threading the wires through the holes one the sides and bending them to prevent them from falling off.

title: Direct Drive extruder for mk8 and 3/8" pneumatic connector

description.text:
Necesitaba un extrusor que calce en los agujeros que tenia en la S-BOX para nema 17 para poder montar 2. Además tenía solo acoples de 3/8" a 4mm por lo que los que vi no me servían. Tomé ideas de varios que hay en este sitio y lo dibujé en Sketchup. Publico las fuentes también por si a alguien le sirve para modificarlo. Hasta ahora anda joya. Le metí los tubitos de ptfe para ayudar al filamento de 1,75, pero calculo que sin los tubos puede andar en 3mm (no lo probé). Mi polea MK tiene 7mm de diámetro en la parte mas fina del hobbed.
Para imprimir el segundo usé la opción de mirror en el slicer.
Para "roscar" el acople rápido lo calenté con una pistola de calor un toque. Agregue el archivo extrusor_idler que es el reemplazo del arnterior P2, solo se modificaron un poco las alturas dado que el otro quedaba muy al borde del filamento y cada tanto se encimaba.

Agrego la versión 2. Luego de casi 7-8 meses de uso, se me rompieron un par de veces los idler por la fuerza que hace el ruleman. Asi que rediseñe un poco el idler para usar un ruleman mas chico (624z) y poder usar de eje un M4 (el M8 no me entraba ni en pedo en ese espacio) Hasta ahora todas las pruebas que hice con el nuevo modelo me anduvieron mucho mejor que el anterior. Subo las nuevas fuentes y los STL por si a alguien le sirve.
Just a direct drive extruder to be mounted on nema17 separation holes. Version 2 has a stronger idler.
Added version 3. you will need the nema17 spacer and both parts.

Se agrega la version 3 tiene un separador para el motor y permitir que la parte que guia al filamento se imprima mas cerca de la polea mk8. Simple pero vengo usando esta versión con sus modificaciones desde hace rato sin problemas. Se recomienda para los conectores neumaticos que no permiten que el tubo de ptfe pase de largo comerles el tope asi no hay que usar pedazos cortados, lo probé asi con flexible y funciona sin darle mucha rosca de velocidad.

author: diegognavarro

description.text:
When I first saw this locket in the movie the Illusionist I had been wanting to make one but didn't have the tools. Eventually I found a design online to make the parts and made some modifications to make the part solid and print effectively. The printer I have is an M3D printer and I found that printing these out on the sides with the round part up creates the best print. I will post pictures soon on the completed file. Some sanding my be required after print to get everything to fit right. I printed it out on a high resolution and each part took about an hour. Feel free to message me if you would like the Fusion 360 files. UPDATE 11/15/15
Ok, so I updated the design so all the parts match up. Now I need to figure out a way to keep all the pieces together. I am thinking about trying to add magnets to the design to keep everything together. These will probably go on the 20 & 21 parts. I think two other magnets will be needed on the bottom points of the heart to allow for rotation once the locket is opened. Feel free to comment if you have any suggestions. Cheers,

title: Bed corner for mounting a 3/16 Aluminum Build Plate

description.text: This is just a slightly modified bed corner piece for mounting a 12" x 12" x 3/16" Aluminum bed plate with your choice of coating (PEI, Buildtak, Bare, Etc.) to your TAZ. It should fit most if not all of the cirrent ones out there. Requires 2 3mm heat set inserts per corner, sourced from Mcmaster Carr http://www.mcmaster.com/#94180a333/=zkm85f and the stock corner hardware and bed retention fingers. The Aluminum bed spreads heat much more evenly across its surface. Please note that the edges of the bed also get fairly warm, so use care when extracting parts. The side swill be hotter than with a glass bed by quite a bit.

An experiment to create an accurate helical coil in OpenSCAD using the linear_extrude function. In order for this to work, a polygon representing the end section of the spring had to be calculated first.
To derive this equation
1) Started with a circle representing the cross section of a round wire.
2) This wire will be angled by the spring's pitch angle, so the cross section gets stretched into an ellipse by scaling one of the axis.
3) Then this ellipse gets distorted by wrapping it around the mean coil diameter.
4) Finally use extrude this shape vertically while twisting it. It was an interesting math challenge and the result looks pretty good. It generates very quickly even at high detail, though you may run out of memory if detail is too high!

This is a reworked update of Things 614962 and 652717.
The geometry has been corrected to give a more truly linear output, and some fixing points have been enlarged for greater robustness.
A complete set of stl file have been uploaded here.
The model is based on mechanism 329 from 507movements.com.
Designed in Moi and made in PLA on an Ultimaker 1. An animation created in Blender is available here: https://youtu.be/T4Nh_J__8oU
A video of the printed model is available here: https://youtu.be/Cy_rkiBq3vw
Note the flexing!

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2 mm layers

Infill:

40%

Notes: Please check orientation prior to printing.
I used PLA and recommend it over ABS for this application.
I recommend 1.2mm walls and 40% fill.
For the larger prints I used a brim.
I used support for one item only - the smaller gear. This was a disadvantage of the improved geometry. In the earlier version I cheated a bit on the geometry to make the gear easier to print but when I (recently) created an animation of the older version I was a bit shocked by how much adverse effect the cheat had on the linearity of the output. Hence the redesign.

Generally I design holes in which something rotates to a nominal dimension such as 6mm diameter or 8mm diameter and the male parts about 0.3mm of 0.4mm under nominal.
Post printing I use hand reamers to bring the holes to the correct size and roundness.

comments.text:
Thanks.
In answer to your question - no, I'm afraid not really,
The problem is that when the 'piston' is fully back, and when it is fully forward, everything is in-line.
If you look at the first photo which shows the piston not quite fully extended you can imagine the slight rotation to make it fully extended and then the piston rod would be exactly in-line with the centre of the small gear so there would be no leverage to rotate the small gear.
When not fully out (nor fully back) then, yes, it can be operated in reverse.
If you can overcome that problem....

comments.text: if your running a reprap maybe lower your extruder min temp? description.text:
This e-NABLE hand is equipped with an early prototype (#3) of a tested and working bidirectional communications link to the e-NABLE servers and back to the hand. This link is accomplished over WiFi using the small yet powerful ESP8266 module. The purpose of the link is to provide usage data for the improvement of the quality of e-NABLE's hands and arms. Total cost is under $20 USD and like a young puppy it can learn new tricks. Right now all it does is report the battery voltage every 10 minutes (approximagely) to the central servers which log each report in a text file. Soon we hope to add closures per hour as a second metric. The device is also capable of receiving commands from the central servers, hand-to-hand communications, audio, video, sensors and actuator control. For now, however it is only being tested with usage data. I sparked the idea in the e-NABLE G+ group and it caught on gradually with other members. Now e-NABlE Phone Home is a full-blown project with beta testers, retired engineers, college students, a professor, and soon we hope to include Veteran's Administration (VA) military folks in the whole project. Though it appears quite large on this 100% hand (the smallest standard hand size), it can easily miniaturize to a much smaller size, plus larger hands for kids and adults can handle the size better. After all, it's a prototype and prototypes are big and bulky then get miniaturized later. If you have expertise to offer our project or just have an interest in it, or for any other reason would like to participate in the e-NABlE phenomenon, please visit our website: www.enablingthefuture.org Thanks,
Les

Just a simple T-slot nut for Aluminium extrusion with profile 8. In my case - it's 40x40. I'm printing 115 of these nuts for my huge delta 3D printer.
Instructions: Print the part without supports - they are build in its construction. The nut is square nut M6 DIN 562 (low profile). The infill varies...but I have good strength properties of the part with 50%, printed with black PLA. It's not so fun removing the supports but be very careful and remove it with a sharp knife. Hold the part with pliers - it's very important! The nut goes in with a little bit of force - I am using just a cheap regular clamp for that purpose.
Best regards!

I stripped away some of the architecture of the previous hinge so this prints faster and still in one piece. I decided that rather than print my final project in one piece i needed to make it modular so that if a single print fails the whole thing isn't kaput. The project i am working on would have been a 3-4 day print easy - and with the threat of weather related power outages, filament chokes, mechanical failure etc i can't take that chance. So after some back and forth i settled on tbusers pins - http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:10541 - made some connecting points and did a quick test print to verify it would work before printing this one. also included is an image of one of the connecting parts, it's a surface with http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:25189 by PrettySmallThings on it. My goal is to connect multiple surfaces to multiple hinges over the next week for a deadline in 7 days time and enter it in an art exhibition / call for works here in Chicago. The exhibition asks for new takes on print on demand books / photography books. Thus i am making the first iteration of my design for a 3d printed accordion book - using 3d scans created using 123d catch - which is after all a photographic technique. Hopefully the judges do not dismiss this proposition. ^_^ This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://tinkercad.com/things/kNSTBuXhHpT

comments.text:
Looks quite sturdy and usable overall, but the knobs at the end of the prongs seems to be the weak spot though (at least with FDM).
To make it last longer, you could add chamfers to all sides of the knobs that don't have to be perpendicular.
comments.author: universalist

comments.text:
"the knobs at the end of the prongs seems to be the weak spot though" - That´s what I thougt. But I´m afraid I can´t add chamfers - the knobs won´t snap in then.
By pushing the male part into the female, the sides of the male are bend to the middle. Just at the end, they spring to the outside again an snap in - with those knobs.
comments.author: universalist

description.text:
Full size train turntable compatible with Brio, Thomas, Ikea and similar wooden track train playsets.  The turntable is sized to accommodate expressed sized engines like Gordon.
Connecting track pieces can be attached to the turntable base to allow for any configuration of tracks and sidings.  There is even a barrier piece to stop engines running off the side like Gordon did.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Infill:

30%

Notes: I printed out the base and tracks with honeycomb infill and without any bottom layers. I also used Laywood for the track pieces.
Designed in OpenSCAD
Mount to zip-tie an extruder (or whatever you want) to the Y-axis sandwich of a Printrbot Jr. This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://tinkercad.com/things/dF7mqg9BZ7X

Print it (I did it with the 0.35mm nozzle at 0.35mm layer height with 0.15 rectilinear fill, but it should be fairly tolerant of various settings)  
Try to press it onto your Y-axis sandwich as depicted. If the alignment is totally off, your sandwich has really different layer thicknesses than mine (which given all the wood is easily possible). If that's the case, measure the differences and head over to Tinkercad and modify the model.  
Zip tie the motor to the platform using whichever 2 out of the 3 slots are most convenient for your type of extruder.
